title: brexit roma gypsies travellers windrush immigration paperwork
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsTravellers fear they could face the same threats of deportation as Windrush GenerationClick to followIndy PoliticsImmigration lawyer Christopher Desira warned that travellers should start gathering paperwork such as tax documentsTravellers and Roma gypsies have been warned about the risk of deportation after Brexit if they fail to possess the correct paperwork,&nbspamid fears of a&nbspWindrush-style&nbspcrackdown by the Home Office.Those at risk&nbsphave been urged to gather as many official documents as possible in case they are asked to prove their residency in the UK after the country leaves the EU.At the Traveller Movement national annual conference, community leaders discussed the difficulties many from the Roma and traveller communities may face proving they have lived in the UK for at least five years.Woman set to become UK's first Roma barrister on Brexit insecurityMany feared they could face the same threats of deportation as the Windrush Generation in the years after Brexit because of lack of official paperwork.Low levels of literacy, digital illiteracy, cost, lack of awareness of the implications of Brexit and deep distrust of state institutions such as the Home Office were all cited as barriers preventing travellers and Roma gypsies applying for settled status by the deadline of June 30 2021.Immigration lawyer Christopher Desira warned that travellers should start gathering paperwork such as tax documents, education certificates, bank statements or employment contracts if they do not have a passport in case they are asked to prove they have lived in the UK for at least five years.The Home Office is particularly worried about fraud, he said.He said that in an extreme scenario, travellers unable to prove their residency could be held indefinitely in a detention centre, despite having no country of origin other than the UK.Mr Desira said such an outcome was unlikely for which is an online process - was also a problem.Our work with (Roma communities) found that there was also a very low awareness of the need to apply to secure their position in the UK.Now they know there is this application, but it's £65 - No.&nbspDidn’t he do enough damage first time round?? Please spare us all.”Redcar MP Anna Turley said: “The sense of entitlement is unreal. title: fracking conservatives shale gas planning mark menzies zac goldsmith
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsProposal to make fast-track new shale gas projects is ‘ludicrous’, says one MPClick to followIndy PoliticsFracking has faced heavy opposition at the Preston New Road site in LancashireThe government's plans to fast-track new&nbspfracking&nbspprojects have been described as&nbsp“ludicrous” and “downright bonkers”, by their own MPs.&nbsp&nbspPoliticians from all parties lined up at a&nbspparliamentary debate to criticise a&nbspproposal to reclassify exploratory fracking wells as permitted developments, under rules originally introduced to speed up projects like small property extensions.&nbspThe government has stated it wishes to make such decisions “faster and fairer”, but opponents said&nbspit would make fracking as easy as putting up a garden shed.Fracking halted in Lancashire for third time after biggest tremor yetFracking has proved a contentious topic in recent weeks as the first well in seven years has been the site of protests and seen off a legal challenge to block it. Operations at Preston New Road, Lancashire,&nbsphave stopped three times due to concerns about earth tremors.The government has stated it wishes to make such decisions “faster and fairer”, but opponents say it would make fracking as easy as putting up a garden shed.Mark Menzies, a Conservative MP whose Fylde constituency includes the Preston New Road site, cited the massive infrastructure developments needed at new fracking sites including “a 30-metre drilling rig”.“Now, who on Earth thinks that is equivalent to building a little extension on the side of your bungalow? It is not,” he said.&nbsp“Moving to permitted development is nothing short of irresponsible and downright bonkers.”Zac Goldsmith, Conservative MP for Richmond Park, said the government supporting fracking while blocking new onshore wind developments was “inexplicably inconsistent” and evidence of “policy that is driven more by ideology than anything else”.Created with Sketch.How fracking works and where it could happen Show all 2Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.There are reportedly up to 20 Conservative MPs ready to rebel over the government’s plan, which critics say would effectively strip local people of the ability to block fracking applications.Tories from constituencies facing new fracking sites including Kevin Hollinrake and Lee Rowley expressed their concerns that people’s voices would be taken away.Mr Rowley, who chairs the all-party parliamentary group on the impact of shale gas, has questioned whether it will be possible for fracking plans to ever be scaled up into a workable industry in the UK.The same concerns have recently been expressed by Francis Egan, the chief executive of oil and gas firm Cuadrilla, which operates the site in Lancashire.With persistent earth tremors repeatedly halting proceedings since they began at the site two weeks ago, Mr Egan has stated the current regulatory system could stop fracking becoming commercially viable in the UK.Under the traffic light system currently used by the industry, fracking must stop whenever it causes tremors with a magnitude above 0.5.&nbspOne independent study estimated that over 6,000 wells will be needed to make it a practical option to supply gas to the UK’s energy system.&nbspThe most recent estimate by the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS) suggested there will be 155 wells by 2025, although energy minister Claire Perry has stated this figure is now “out of date”.Hundreds of thousands urge government to stop fast-tracking frackingDaniel Carey-Dawes, senior infrastructure campaigner at the Campaign to Protect Rural England said the debate was a clear demonstration of the widespread growing anger&nbsp– by MPs on all sides of the political spectrum – towards the government’s plans to fast-track fracking.The government recently closed its consultation on whether new shale exploration sites should be treated as permitted developments.&nbspResponding to the concerns raised at the debate, housing minister Kit Malthouse said the government remained “fully committed to ensuring that local communities are fully involved in planning decisions that affect them, and to making planning decisions faster and fairer”.“Those are long-standing principles and I am adamant that we should stick to them.”BEIS has emphasised the role it sees for natural gas in meeting the UK’s climate targets, and the role fracking can play in this.The Independent has launched its #FinalSay campaign to demand that voters are title: smacking ban scotland children scottish government holyrood consulation
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsLegislation is expected to be passed following backing&nbspfrom Scottish government and&nbspMSPsClick to followIndy PoliticsMembers of the public are being asked to give their views on proposed legislation to ban smacking children in Scotland.Holyrood’s Equalities and Human Rights Committee has launched a call for views on the Children (Equal Protection from Assault) (Scotland) Bill.Introduced by Green MSP John Finnie as a private member’s Bill it would, if passed, remove the defence of “justifiable assault” in Scots law, which allows parents to use physical punishment on children.Bans on smacking children ‘linked to lower violence among teens’The legislation is expected to be passed as it has been backed by the Scottish Government and MSPs from across all the political parties.A recent Panelbase poll of 1,024 voters for The Sunday Times Scotland found 30 per cent backed a ban, while 53 per cent&nbspbelieve smacking should still be allowed and the remainder were unsure.However, a public consultation last year received more than 650 responses with almost 75 per cent of those in favour of a ban.Organisations including the Scottish Police Federation, Barnardo’s Scotland, the Church and Society Council of the Church of Scotland and the NSPCC also back outlawing smacking.Welsh parents could be banned from smacking their childrenCampaign group Be Reasonable Scotland, supported by The Christian Institute and The Family Education Trust, argues a ban will “criminalise parents”.Equalities and Human Rights Committee Convener, Ruth Maguire, said: “This Bill has aroused strong views.“There are passionately held beliefs on both sides of this argument, from those who think that physical punishment violates a child’s human rights, to those who feel parents should have a right to smack their children.“As the proposed law starts making its way through the Parliamentary process, we are keen to hear from people in Scotland who have a view on this subject.“This will help us as we carry out our role as parliamentarians and inform our consideration of the proposals.“While committee members will be title: tracey crouch resigns sports minister delay betting fixed odds government
story: Created with Sketch.Subscribe  registerSubscribeJoin us Subscribe  registerJoin us SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsMP suggests failure to introduce change until next October could result in hundreds more people killing themselves because of gambling problemsClick to followIndy PoliticsTracey Crouch has resigned as&nbspsports minister after the government refused&nbspto back down on the timetable for slashing&nbspthe maximum stake for&nbsphighly-addictive gambling machines.The MP had lobbied&nbspfor&nbspthe change to be made earlier than the planned date of October 2019 but quit after senior ministers refused to budge.Betting&nbspcompanies&nbsphad reportedly said they would be ready to implement the cut to fixed-odds betting terminal (FOBTs) stakes by next April, but the government confirmed&nbspin the Budget that the change would not be made until next October.Ms Crouch suggested the delay could result in&nbsphundreds more people killing themselves because of&nbspgambling-related problems.Maximum bet on ‘crack cocaine’ gambling machines slashed to £2In her resignation letter to Theresa May, she&nbspwelcomed the cut in the maximum FOBT stake from £100 to £2&nbspbut wrote:&nbsp”Unfortunately, implementation of these changes are now being delayed until October 2019 due to commitments made by others to those with registered interests.“From the time of the announcement to reduce stakes and its implementation, over £1.6bn will be lost on these machines, a significant amount of which will be in our most deprived areas, including my own constituency. In addition, two people will tragically take their life&nbspevery day due to gambling related problems and for that reason as much as any other I believe this delay is unjustifiable.”There was “no reason why implementation cannot come in sooner than October”, she added.Tom Watson, Labour’s deputy leader and shadow culture secretary, welcomed Ms Crouch’s resignation and accused Jeremy Wright, the culture secretary, of having “prioritised corporate interests over victims”.He wrote on Twitter: “Tracey Crouch has taken a courageous and principled decision to resign from the government over Jeremy Wright’s decision to delay cutting the maximum stake on FOBTs.“She poured her heart and soul into a significant review of these destructive machines, faced down a systematic lobbying attempt by the gambling industry and took the right decision for those suffering from problem gambling, their families and communities.“The new secretary of state has threatened all of this good work.&nbspHe has prioritised corporate interests over victims, profits over public health and greed over good.&nbsp He should be thoroughly ashamed.”Created with Sketch.UK news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Google staff stage a walkout at the company's UK headquarters in London as part of a global campaign over the US tech giant's handling of sexual harassment. Society saysClick to followIndy PoliticsFemale MPs at the launch of Labour's campaign to celebrate 100 years of women's suffrage on College Green in WestminsterWomen face obstacles at every stage of trying to get into Parliament, a study has said.There is particular resistance against female candidates from gatekeepers in political parties, research by the Fawcett Society said.Women experience multiple barriers to being selected as candidates simply because of their sex, according to the report.English Heritage calls for more blue plaques dedicated to womenThe Fawcett Society, which describes itself as a charity campaigning for gender equality, surveyed 113 MPs of both sexes, and used focus groups of politically involved women as part of its study.Women seeking political office are still being asked about their martial status and children, the report said.Local parties resist women because they are seeking a preconceived ideal candidate who is white, male, middle-class and able-bodied, according to the study.Many female candidates experienced abuse or harassment from the media, the public and from members of their own party, the Fawcett Society said.The study said: Long and anti-social working hours were cited by a number of MPs as being a problem including the expectation that you are available to constituents around the clock, and the need to live in two places.The culture of Westminster was also cited as being a barrier.The report found that women are more likely to stand if asked to do so.Of the MPs surveyed, 75 per cent&nbspof women said they ran for Parliament because someone asked them to, compared with 54 per cent of men.Fawcett Society chief executive Sam Smethers said Dame Laura Cox's report into a culture of harassment at Westminster had title: Brexit news live update theresa may eu uk financial services deal
story: The Bank of England left interest rates unchanged at 0.75 per cent, but stressed it was poised to respond in either direction as it awaits the outcome of Brexit talks.Members of the Bank's nine-strong Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) voted unanimously to keep rates on hold after August's quarter-point hike and as it remains in wait-and-see mode amid Brexit uncertainty.In its quarterly inflation report published alongside the rates decision, the Bank sketched out how it could respond to various Brexit scenarios, signalling that it could even be forced to raise rates should a disorderly exit send the pound tumbling.The bank said: The monetary policy response to Brexit, whatever form it takes, will not be automatic and could be in either direction.&nbsp                German carmakers could be to BLAME for Eurozone economic slowdown -...                US TRADE WAR: China SMASHED by Donald Trump battle as yuan slidesThe report also predicted business investment has screeched to a complete halt overall this year as uncertainty wreaks havoc on company spending decisions.In a press conference following the publication of the inflation report, Bank Governor Mark Carney warned interest rates could rise in the event of a no-deal Brexit if a cliff-edge withdrawal sends the pound into freefall.Mr Carney said there are scenarios where policy might need to be tightened in the event of a no deal, no transition Brexit, should a plunge in the value of the pound cause inflation to surge and impact UK production.He stressed a no-deal Brexit was not the most likely scenario, but said the Bank had to be prepared for the worst case and this could mean rates moving in either direction.The Bank's boss also cautioned that monetary policy might not be able to help soften the economic blow of a no-deal disorderly Brexit.He said: There is little that monetary policy can do to offset large, negative supply shocks, which occur relatively rarely in advanced economies.&nbspBrexit news: The Bank of England has warned of interest rate hikes  (Image: EPA )The bank said consumer spending had been helping prop up the economy, with a summer heatwave shopping spree set to see growth accelerate to 0.6 percent in the third quarter, up from 0.4 percent in the previous three months.&nbspBut this is likely to have been only a temporary boost, and the Bank expects growth to pare back to 0.3 percent in the fourth quarter before steadying at 0.4 percent thereafter.This saw the Bank trim its forecast for growth overall in 2018, to 1.3 percent from 1.4 percent predicted in August, while it also nudged its 2019 outlook down to 1.7 percent from 1.8percent.Its forecasts are based on a smooth exit from the EU, with financial markets pencilling in around one rate rise a year for the next three years.However, the Bank admits the economic outlook will depend significantly on the nature of EU withdrawal.It comes after it was reported Theresa May had secured another Brexit victory after the EU caved in to allow UK financial services continued access to the Brussels bloc after Britain&rsquos exit.UK and EU negotiators were understood to have reached a tentative agreement on their future relationship surrounding services, as well as the exchange of data, with just five months to go before Britain leaves.But Number 10 said the reports were speculation and talks were ongoing, while the EU's Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier hit out at misleading accounts.Follow Express for live Brexit updates below:Brexit news: Mark Carney speaks following the Bank of England's statement  (Image: PA )                Barclays Brexit BLOW: Bank steps up plans to move EU hub from London                 Saudi Arabia CRISIS: King's youngest brother in bid to OVERTHROW ru...10.30pm: Brussels &lsquoconsdiering new Irish backstop compromise&rsquoEU negotiators are preparing to budge on their demands for the Irish border backstop, the Financial Times has reported.Brussels is reportedly considering &lsquonew&rsquo terms which would provide a stronger guarantee&nbspthat a customs border would not be needed along the Irish Sea.The EU&rsquos proposals would still require Northern Ireland to remain in the bloc&rsquos customs union to avoid a hard border in Ireland in the event of a no-deal Brexit.But the revised offer would also include a &ldquobare-bones customs arrangement with the EU which would apply to the rest of the UK, according to the FT.The plan has reportedly been floated with UK officials and Britain is said to be considering the offer with a view to issuing a response next week.6.15pm: Travellers urged to gather documents to prove residency after BrexitAn immigration lawyer has warned members of the traveller community and Roma gypsies to begin gathering official paperwork in case they are required to prove their residency status after Britain leaves the EU.Christopher Desira said travellers should start gathering paperwork such as tax documents, education certificates, bank statements or employment contracts if they do not have a passport in case they are asked to prove they have lived in the UK for at least five years.His warning comes after community leaders at the Traveller Movement national annual conference voiced concern over the threat of deportation after Brexit.4pm: Ireland &lsquoriding roughshod&rsquo over Good Friday Agreement with Brexit border demandsFormer Northern Ireland first minister Lord Trimble has weighed in on the Irish border debate by warning Belfast could become an &ldquoEU protectorate if the UK agrees to Dublin&rsquos demands.The Nobel peace prize winner blasted Leo Varadkar&rsquos government for attempting to push for Brexit terms which &ldquogo well beyond the avoidance of a hard border.Lord Trimble said Dublin is &ldquoriding roughshod over the terms of the Good Friday Agreement and &ldquoviolating its spirit.Harvey Gavin taking over form Rebecca Perring on live reporting.Nobel peace prize laureate Lord Trimble warned Northern Ireland could become an 'EU protectorate' (Image:  IMAGES)2.39pm update: Ed Miliband describes Brexit vote a 'cry of pain'&nbspThe former Labour leader said the Leave result was a cry of pain at loss of hope and the loss of a sense of community - in part derived from the fall in social housebuilding.He added: There's nothing more likely to unite people across the ide than long-term investment in social housing.2.16pm update:&nbspBritain may not have time to negotiate a new deal if MPs decide to amend any Brexit agreement - senior ministerCommons Leader Andrea Leadsom said the Government would take action on any amendments to the Brexit deal motion approved by MPs but added that it may not be possible for ministers to proceed on the basis of an amended vote.Her remarks came after Conservative former cabinet minister Ken Clarke warned the Government against offering MPs the choice of deal or no deal.1.34pm update:&nbspLeading economists have cast doubt on Hammond's claim that a Brexit deal idend will provide a boost to the UKIn Monday's Budget, the Chancellor said that a Brexit agreement would deliver a double boost to the economy, as businesses and households were freed from uncertainty and the Treasury was able to spend some of the &pound15.4 billion&nbspbuffer&nbspit is holding in reserve to cope with a possible no-deal outcome.However, experts from&nbspbusiness&nbsporganisation the CBI and the Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) played down the prospect of a major boost.IFS director Paul Johnson acknowledged there were some forecasters in the City who believed that agreement with Brussels could unlock some additional investment if the disaster of a no-deal Brexit is avoided.Former Labour leader Ed Miliband said a lack of social housing contributed to Brexit (Image:  IMAGES)12.46pm update:&nbspBarnier and Downing Street have played down speculation about a breakthrough in Brexit talksReports that a Brexit deal could safeguard the City's access to EU markets led to an increase in the value of sterling.But Number 10 said it was speculation and talks were ongoing, while the&nbspEU's Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier hit out at misleading accounts.12.31pm update:&nbspThe Bank of England has left interest rates unchanged at 0.75 percentBut stressed it was poised to respond in either direction as it awaits the outcome of Brexit talks.Members of the Bank's nine-strong Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) voted unanimously to keep rates on hold after August's quarter-point hike and as it remains in wait-and-see mode amid Brexit uncertainty.In its quarterly inflation report published alongside the rates decision, the Bank sketched out how it could respond to various Brexit scenarios, signalling that it could even be forced to raise rates should a disorderly exit send the pound tumbling.The bank warned: The monetary policy response to Brexit, whatever form it takes, will not be automatic and could be in either direction.&nbspBrexit news: Arron Banks has been referred to the National Crime Agency (Image: PA )12.16pm update: Leave campaigner Arron Banks referred to National Crime AgencyThe Electoral Commission referred Mr Banks for suspected criminal offences committed during the EU referendum.The probe has been launched after the elections watchdog said it had reasonable grounds to suspect that Mr Banks was not the true source of &pound8 million worth of loans made during the campaign.Leave.EU, co-founded by Mr Banks, its chief executive Elizabeth Bilney and the organisation that ran it, Better for the Country, are also being investigated by the NCA after a review carried out by the Electoral Commission.Bob Posner, the Commission's director of political finance, said: We have reasonable grounds to suspect money given to Better for the Country came from impermissible sources and that Mr Banks and Ms Bilney, the responsible person for Leave.EU, knowingly concealed the true circumstances under which this money was provided.This is significant because at least &pound2.9m of this money was used to fund referendum spending and donations during the regulated period of the EU referendum.12.04am update: Almost two-thirds of Scots believe a second vote on Brexit would result in the UK remaining in the EUResearch by Survation found 64 percent found a so-called People's Vote would reverse the result of the 2016 referendum.The results, published to coincide with the launch of the Scotland for a People's Vote campaign, also found almost three-fifths of Scots (59 percent) support having a vote on the terms of the UK's final Brexit deal, with 41 percent against this.Overall support for staying in the European Union was slightly stronger in Scotland than it was in 2016 referendum.That ballot saw the UK as a whole narrowly vote to leave, despite 62 percent of voters north of the border backing remain.In the poll, 63 percent of people said they supported staying in the EU, with 37 percent opposed to this.Brexit news: The UK and EU have agreed on a financial services deal  (Image:  )10.29am update:&nbspFury at Madrid as Gibraltar 'handed' to May in EASY Brexit victoryThe Spanish government has come under fire after handing Britain a significant Brexit victory by conceding in its bid for joint control of Gibraltar.Madrid had threatened to veto the entire Brexit deal over sovereignty of the Rock but instead rolled over and stopped in its challenge for the British Overseas territory.Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez was accused of failing to make the most of a &ldquohistoric opportunity to &ldquodecolonise Gibraltar, according to angry opposition politicians.10.01am update: Arch-Remainer John Major has been accused of &lsquoHIDING facts&rsquo on Maastricht TreatyThe former Prime Minister was slammed over comments he made about Danish proposals on the controversial and fiercely opposed treaty in October 1992.The treaty &ndash that established what we now know as the European Union &ndash took almost a year to be ratified as Sir John battled with Labour and Conservative eurosceptics to push it through.Now, on the 25th anniversary of ratification, a statement accusing the former Tory leader of &ldquomisleading the country has re-emerged.9.26am update: Michel Barnier&nbspis under growing pressure to crack and finally accept Theresa May&rsquos Brexit proposalsSenior European sources disclosed on Wednesday night that the EU&rsquos chief Brexit negotiator is being pressured to compromise with the UK.It comes as EU members states privately voiced their concerns over Mr Barnier&rsquos &ldquobackstop agreement, as they claim it will never be accepted by Theresa May.Under the current EU offer, Northern Ireland would be locked in the EU&rsquos customs union and its single market for goods.The plan has caused uproar amongst Brexiteers and the Democratic Unionist Party, whose 10 Northern Irish MPs prop up the Prime Minister&rsquos minority Government with a supply and confidence agreement.9.10am update: EU says London will still be key finance hub&nbspBrussels looked to calm Brexit concerns by telling traders London will remain a key finance hub - even if Britain tumbles out of the bloc without a deal.&nbspEuropean Commission Vice President Vladis Dombrovskis made the commitment to traders across the continent, reassuring them they will be able to use crucial UK derivatives clearing services regardless of the outcome of Brexit negotiations.But Mr Dombrovskis, who is also responsible for financial regulation, warned the relief allowing EU banks and companies to continue using UK-based clearing houses to process derivatives trades if talks with Brussels collapse, would only be short term.He told the Financial Times this would also have to linked to a willingness from the UK to remain close to European Union regulatory and supervisory standards.The European Commission Vice President warned: &ldquoShould we need to act, we would only do so to the extent necessary to address financial stability risks arising from an exit without a deal, under strict conditionality and with limited duration.Brexit news: The victory will come as a blow to France  (Image:  )8.53am update:&nbspScotland rallies to hold second vote on Brexit&nbspA Scottish campaign calling for people across the UK to have the final say on Brexit will be launched at an event in Edinburgh today.&nbspThere have been cross-party calls for a so-called People's Vote before the UK formally departs the European Union in March 2019.Scotland voted by 62 percent to remain in the EU when the referendum was held in June 2016.Hundreds of campaigners attended a rally in Scotland's capital in August to call for the UK Government's eventual Brexit deal to be put before the country.The event in Edinburgh, organised by the Scotland for a People's Vote campaign group, will feature speakers including Dr Kirsty Hughes, the director of the Scottish Centre on European Relations and John Edward, the former head of the European Parliament Office in Scotland.8.40am update:&nbspSmall firms voice deep concern &nbspover prospect of having to check the eligibility of EU workers if there is no Brexit dealThe Federation of Small Businesses (FSB) said smaller companies would struggle to cope with the additional burden.It comes after&nbspImmigration Minister Caroline Nokes earlier this week that employers will be expected to check whether EU nationals have the right to work in the UK if there is a no-deal Brexit.FSB chairman Mike Cherry said: Small businesses are not the Home Office and should not be expected to undertake their job.The reality is that many of these businesses wouldn't have the first idea of where, or how, to check whether or not their EU staff have the right to work here.Most small firms don't have HR or legal departments to deal with complex immigration procedures, or the time and resources to deal with the additional administrative burden this would bring.8.21am update: Victory for Theresa May as UK and EU agree deal on financial services&nbspWith five months to secure a&nbspBrexit&nbspdeal before Britain is due to leave the EU, business leaders are demanding certainty over the kind of trade terms the orce will deliver.The services deal would give UK companies access to European markets as long as British financial regulation remained broadly aligned with the EU's, The Times reported.&nbspMrs May's principal Europe adviser, Oliver Robbins, is understood to be continuing negotiations in Brussels.Senior figures in London&rsquos financial district welcomed the news but warned of the complications over delivering detail on the deal in a legal trade agreement.One told the newspaper: &ldquoWhen it comes to it, countries like France are going to do everything to make life hard for the City.&ldquoIt is one thing to have warm words in a political declaration that is not binding and tying it down in a legal document.

story: A source whom the former Prime Minister confided in disclosed Mr Cameron would not rule out a return to UK politics if a future Tory leader asked him to come back.The role Mr Cameron would assume is not entirely clear but the insider implied it could be Foreign Secretary.Speaking to The Sun, the source said: &ldquoDavid is dedicated to public service, and has often said he wouldn&rsquot rule out a public role one day, domestically or internationally.&ldquoBut he is only 52, and still a young man.                Brexit warning: UK may be FORCED to SCRAP daylight saving time                Writer ATTACKS George Osborne to his face on BBC Newsnight The former Prime Minister, who initiated the Brexit referendum process which consequently produced the UK&rsquos decision to leave the EU, is planning to release his political memoirs next spring.Any bid to return to Westminster would have to wait until after the book&rsquos release.Mr Cameron has said he wants to hold back on the publication of the potentially explosive biography until after &ldquoBrexit day on March 29, 2019.His reasoning for delaying the memoir&rsquos release date is so revelations from them do not undermine or interfere with the Brexit negotiations.A close friend of David Cameron said he is 'bored sh**less' and may return to UK politics (Image: )Mr Cameron giving his resignation speech outside Number 10 (Image: )During the address to the nation he touted the UK's 'great advantages' (Image: )The old Etonian is expected to use the bombshell book to savagely settle scores with a number of acting senior ministers - in particular, Environment Secretary Michael Gove who shamelessly stabbed Mr Cameron in the front when he spearheaded the Leave campaign.Mr Cameron and Mr Gove had been close friends, often holidaying together with their families before the sensational fallout.The potential return has been met with backlash, with Labour&rsquos Yvette Cooper among those critical of the plan.On Twitter, she said: &ldquoWhat, because it worked out so well last time?                Samantha Cameron makes SHOCK return to 10 Downing Street                 Campbell invites Sky host to 'hit him' as they revisit past clashMichael Gove helped run the Leave campaign defying his leader (Image: )&ldquoMan, you ripped up our closest international partnership. By accident.&ldquoThat makes you even worse than Boris Johnson.Shadow education minister Angela Rayner branded the rumoured return of David Cameron to frontline politics as &ldquobizarre.Ms Rayner tweeted: &ldquoJust when you thought politics couldn't get any more bizarre.Labour's Shadow Foreign Secretary Emily Thornberry was not impressed with the news (Image: )&ldquoNo, David, please stay in retirement you caused enough damage last time.Shadow communities and local government secretary Andrew Gwynne wrote: &ldquoGod. No.&ldquoDidn't he do enough damage first time around?? Please spare us all.Meanwhile, Redcar MP Anna Turley said: &ldquoThe sense of entitlement is unreal. Please go away and think about what you've done, while Emily Thornberry posted a facepalm emoji - a picture used to display frustration or embarrassment at a certain situation.Labour's Yvette Cooper has weighed in on the rumours (Image: Yvette Cooper-Twitter)Mr Cameron quit his premiership after a crushing defeat in the EU Referendum.In part of his leaving speech, he said: &ldquoThe negotiation with the EU will need to begin under a new Prime Minister and I think it is right this new Prime Minister takes the decision about when to trigger Article 50 and start the formal and legal process of leaving the EU.&ldquoThe British people have made a choice that not only needs to be respected but those on the losing side of the argument, myself included, should help to make it work.&ldquoBritain is a special country, we have so many great advantages &ndash a Parliamentary democracy where we resolve great issues about our future through peaceful debate.&ldquoA great trading nation with our science and arts, our engineering and creativity, respected the world over.'And while we are not perfect, I do believe we can be a model of a multiracial, multi-faith democracy where people can come and make a contribution and rise to the very highest their talent allows.

story: Brexit news: Michel Barnier's angry pushback has been dismissed  (Image: )ITV&rsquos Robert Peston said the Treasury had indeed negotiated a &ldquohigh-level agreement with Brussels on aspects of the future partnership just hours after the EU&rsquos chief Brexit negotiator blasted the same claims as &ldquomisleading.Michel Barnier took the unprecedented step on Wednesday of angrily tweeting about reports in the Times that the EU caved in to allow UK financial services continued access to the Brussels bloc after Britain&rsquos exit.This was followed by a furious statement by Downing Street who said the reports were speculation as Brexit talks are still ongoing.But writing in a blog last night, political journalist Mr Peston said: &ldquoIt&rsquos true that a few weeks ago, the Treasury over the course of a couple of days successfully negotiated some &lsquohigh level principles&rsquo for what the future access relationship might be for UK-based banks and other financial institutions to the EU's single market.                'Germany could be PARALYSED' EU fears over lame duck MerkelHowever, Mr Peston said it wasn&rsquot all good news for Britain because the nation is still a &ldquomillion miles from a deal and the agreement would see London become the &ldquorule-taker.Posting on Facebook, he added: &ldquoAn eventual deal would be what's known as an &lsquoequivalence&rsquo arrangement, where the rules for selling to the EU would be set by the EU - and disputes would ultimately be settled by the European Court of Justice.&ldquoThe City of London - responsible for around a tenth of national income, about the same importance to the UK as manufacturing - would be a pure rule taker.Follow Express below for live Brexit updates.8.21am update: Reports David Cameron is returning to frontline politics&nbspThe former prime minister's&nbspclose friend revealed he is &ldquobored s***less two years on from leaving Number 10 and resigning as an MP.A source whom the former Prime Minister confided in disclosed Mr Cameron would not rule out a return to UK politics if a future Tory leader asked him to come back.The role Mr Cameron would assume is not entirely clear but the insider implied it could be Foreign Secretary.Speaking to The Sun, the source said: &ldquoDavid is dedicated to public service, and has often said he wouldn&rsquot rule out a public role one day, domestically or internationally.&ldquoBut he is only 52, and still a young man.

title: Royal news Prince Charles pampered demands projects
story: Prince Charles, 69, is the heir to the throne and will take over when his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, dies.In Amazon Prime documentary Serving the Royals: Inside the Firm, the film reveals the Prince of Wales&rsquo legion of loyal helpers catering to his every whim.The Palace household is lavish and the pampered prince is famously difficult to please with some of his demands being seen as bizarre.Footage shows Princess Diana&rsquos former butler Paul Burrell explaining that Charles has &ldquogrown up in such a privileged lifestyle, he doesn&rsquot have the mechanics to choose for himself anymore.                Royal news: How 'radical' Prince Charles REBELS against the Queen                Fuming Queen Mother helped protect 'sensitive' Charles from PhilipHe adds: &ldquoEverything is done for him.&ldquoHis pyjamas are pressed every morning, his shoe laces are pressed flat with an iron, the bath plug has to be in a certain position, and the water temperature has to be just tepid.Mr Burrell adds that Charles even &ldquohas his valets squeeze one inch of toothpaste onto his toothbrush every morning.He then recalls a moment during his years spent as a Royal butler at the Palace. (Image: Getty)&ldquoOn one occasion, he rang me from his library and he said &lsquoOh Paul, a letter from the Queen seems to have fallen into my wastepaper bin. Would you pick it out?The Prince is accustomed to travelling with his own very specific creature comforts, according to Rebel Prince: The Power, Passion and Defiance of Prince Charles by Tom Bower.The book describes how, before a visit to a friend in North-East England, he despatched his staff ahead a day early with a truck carrying Charles and Camilla&rsquos complete bedrooms, including the Prince&rsquos orthopaedic bed along with his own linen.His staff had also packed a small radio, Charles&rsquos own toilet seat, rolls of Kleenex Premium Comfort toilet paper, Laphroaig whisky and bottled water, plus two landscapes of the Scottish Highlands.Serving the Royals: Inside the Firm is available to watch on Amazon Prime now.

title: eu news john major maastricht treaty hiding facts brexit projects
story: The then Prime Minister was slammed over comments he made about Danish proposals on the controversial and fiercely opposed treaty in October 1992.The treaty &ndash that established what we now know as the European Union &ndash took almost a year to be ratified as Sir John battled with Labour and Conservative eurosceptics to push it through.Now, on the 25th anniversary of ratification, a statement accusing the former Tory leader of &ldquomisleading the country has re-emerged.&nbspIt refers to a speech he made at Lancaster House that was intended to pave the way for a Commons vote on a resumption of ratification.                Moment Thatcher savaged Remainer John Major for &lsquoputting head in fire'                'Brexiteers will PAY!' - Major's BLISTERING Brexit intervention In it, he claimed that the EC &ndash&nbspthe precursor to the EU &ndash was &ldquogetting back on the path and that Danish demands to water down the treaty would not present a problem.He added that the Danes would have to &ldquoswallow their proposed amendments.However, a Foreign Office note delivered to Sir John a week before the speech was delivered claimed the Danish position was &ldquonon-negotiable and &ldquounlikely to be acceptable as it stands to member states.As this news came to light, Jack Cunningham, Labour&rsquos foreign affairs spokesman at the time, said: &ldquoThe Prime Minister is misleading the country and Parliament in his statements on the Danish document.&ldquoHis remarks lack honesty because he must know from the Foreign Office that what he is saying is not the whole truth about the Danish position and its consequences for the treaty and the agreement of the other Community members.John Major signed the Maastricht treaty in 1992 (Image: )John Major shakes hands with French President Francois Mitterrand during Maastricht negotiations (Image: )Denmark wanted safeguards in four key areas: common currency, common defence, European citizenship and operations on immigration and crime.&nbspThe Danes had two referendums on the treaty, with the first vote rejecting it and the second going through following the Edinburgh Agreement that granted the requested concessions.&nbspThe Maastricht Treaty saw the European Community evolve into the European Union with 12 member states initially.&nbspIt also laid down the groundwork for economic and monetary union with a single currency at its heart and new rules on inflation, debt and interest rate regulations.&nbspThe Maastricht treaty was extremely controversial at the time (Image: )After a number of alterations and political manoeuvring, it was finally ratified on November 1, 1993.&nbspThe subsequent fallout with eurosceptic Tories is widely regarded as being a key reason behind the Conservative Party&rsquos collapse ahead of the 1997 General Election.Sir John&rsquos decision to sign the treaty also attracted criticism from Margaret Thatcher, who fiercely opposed the move.&nbspShe said: &ldquoOur trust was not well-founded.&ldquoWe got our fingers burnt. The most silly thing to do when you get your fingers burnt is to bring forward a bigger and worse Act which is the equivalent of putting your head in the fire.Speaking months later in the House of Lords about Maastricht, she added: &ldquoI could never have signed this treaty.                John Major accuses Rees-Mogg of 'intolerably BULLYING' Theresa May                Brexit deal in 21 days: End is in sight says Brexit SecretaryIt comes after Sir John, a prominent Remainer, launched a fresh call for a second vote on Brexit earlier this week.&nbspWriting for the Evening Standard, the former Prime Minister described the UK&rsquos decision to leave the EU as one of the most &ldquoisive in British history.Sir John said: &ldquoOnce more we must look to Parliament to safeguard our interests.&ldquoAs the facts become known, Parliament &ndash our ultimate sovereign power &ndash will need to decide whether the deal presented to them meets the promises made to the British people.Margaret Thatcher was critical of John Major over Maastricht (Image: )John Major and Tony Blair are both prominent Remainers (Image: )&ldquoIf it does not, I believe Parliament would be right to order a 'binding' referendum.&ldquoSuch a further &ndash&nbspand final &ndash referendum would be controversial, especially among those who fear they may lose it. I accept it is not an easy option.&ldquoBut the moral &ndash and democratic &ndash case for voting upon proven facts, rather than peddled fiction, is rock solid.&ldquoThe reverse is also true: how can it be right to hold people to a decision made upon so many false promises?

James McClean poppy: Why does Stoke star not wear a poppy?                White poppy: What is a White Poppy? Why are people wearing it?The short clip, filmed in the in the away stand at Dens Park clearly hears a group of Celtic supporters singing: &ldquoYou can shove your f****** poppy, shove your f****** poppy, shove your f****** poppy up&nbspyour&nbspa***.The video sparked a furious debate on social media with some online commentators branding the attack &ldquoshameful.Some claimed the song was &ldquodisrespectful to men who &ldquogave their lives.One wrote: &ldquoScotland's shame. Awful supporters.Another said: &ldquoAbsolutely disgusting.A third said: &ldquoThe poppy Is a symbol of remembrance to commemorate servicemen and women killed in conflicts.&ldquoCeltic fans deliberately misunderstand meaning for own agenda, respect your ancestors for allowing you to even be at that football game today #NoRespect.The video posted on social media has been viewed more than 65,000&nbsptimes.Celtic supporters were filming chanting an anti-poppy song (Image: DEADLINENEWS)Stoke footballer James McClean has faced backlash by refusing to wear a poppy on Remembrance Day again.In a statement, he said: &ldquoI know many people won&rsquot agree with my decision or even attempt to gain an understanding of why I don&rsquot wear a poppy.&ldquoI accept that but I would ask people to be respectful of the choice I have made, just as I&rsquom respectful of people who do choose to wear a poppy.The 29-year-old is from Derry where the Bloody Sunday incident occurred in 1972.

title: Brexit news UK EU latest no deal vote transition Theresa May Michel Barnier referendum
story: Britain secured a 21-month transition with the European Union in March, set to start when Britain leaves the Brussels bloc on 29 March 2019 and end in December 2020.Tory MP Daniel Kawczynski hit back at claims Prime Minister Theresa May could extend the transition if she fails to find a solution to the Irish border issue.Speaking to Express, Mr Kawczynski said: &ldquoI think that that process has been set in stone. There is a specific path to this and I think that we have to make the decision within the time frames.&ldquoI think it would be destabilising sort of narrative if we said &lsquono we are not ready and we are going to extend the deadline&rsquo. No. I think this focus of the 29 March of next year is very important.                John Major claims he should have BYPASSED Tory backbenchers&ldquoIt&rsquos really focussing the minds of people now to get that deal sorted out. Apparently, according to the European Union, 85 percent of everything has been agreed, it is the last difficult 15 percent that hasn&rsquot been finished.&ldquoI think if you extend the deadline you are saying a couple of things, first of all we failed to negotiate.&ldquoSecondly, it is almost like giving a green light to potentially reversing the decision or going along with the ludicrous proposition that there is another referendum. No.&ldquoThe decision has been taken. We are pulling out of the European Union on March 29 next year.Brexit news: Daniel Kawczynski says the Brexit process has been set in stone (Image: &bull)The Tory Brexiteer also revealed he has constituents heading down to Parliament for a celebratory dinner to honour &ldquosomething quite unique.He added: &ldquoThe creation of a new sovereign nation on the continent of Europe &ndash that is a very very special thing.The Prime Minister could accept a proposal from Brussels to extend the transition period following Brexit to provide more time to resolve the Irish border issue.Theresa May was in Brussels in October for the European Council summit in hope of breaking the longstanding deadlock in Brexit negotiations, with the Irish border issue remaining to be the key issue.The Prime Minister said &ldquoone option being considered is to extend the transition period but only &ldquofor a matter of months.But later on in the day, Mrs May attempted to play down the comments and said Britain will not be pushing for an extension to the Brexit transition period.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab said in a letter to the House of Common&rsquos Brexit committee that he believes a deal is reachable within three weeks.Government sources also claimed on Thursday that British and EU negotiators have reached a deal on all aspects on the future partnership on series and the exchange of data.Under the agreement, UK financial services firms would be guaranteed access to European markets as long as British financial regulations remained aligned with Europe.But Mr Barnier warned Mrs May that the EU will never give up its right to autonomously deny access to its financial markets.Writing on Twitter, the EU negotiator said: &ldquoThe EU may grant and withdraw equivalence in some financial services autonomously.&ldquoAs with other third countries, EU is ready to have close regulatory dialogue with the UK in full respect for autonomy of both parties.

story: The Socialist politician stunned her British colleague John Procter when she suggested concluding the Brexit negotiations in a no deal could result in Britain not leaving the European Union.Ms Jo&atildeo Rodrigues insisted it was her belief the UK could not have Brexit unless the British Government secured a withdrawal agreement with Brussels after resolving the Irish border issue currently deadlocking the talks.Speaking to Raw Politics, the Portuguese MEP said: I don&rsquot believe there is Brexit but there is no deal. There is no deal if there is no full respect for citizens&rsquo rights and I believe the Irish problem is part of this.We cannot exclude a no deal but if there is no deal, I think there is no Brexit. That is my assumption.                Tory Brexiteer SHUTS DOWN calls to delay Brexit with THIS point                UK property: House prices drop in October due to Brexit and BudgetMr Procter immediately rebuked his colleague's claims, pointing out the Government has already adopted clear legislation &ndash such as the EU Withdrawal Bill &ndash to prepare the country to leave the European Union in March 2019.The Brexiteer MEP appeared adamant the UK will not backtrack on its decision, saying the UK will simply time-out from the bloc should negotiations result in a no deal scenario.Mr Procted said: That simply won&rsquot be the case. The UK Government&rsquos on a clear path, there&rsquos legislation that&rsquos in place within the UK. If there&rsquos no deal we&rsquoll simply time-out.The clock is ticking, that was clear when Article 50 was served. The UK will simply leave the European Union come the end of March. That&rsquos a fact.Brexit news: Ms Jo&atildeo Rodrigues claimed a no deal could result in no Brexit (Image: EURONEWS)Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab told MPs in a letter to the House of Commons' Brexit committee he believes a deal could be potentially reached within three weeks.Mr Raab insisted an arrangement is in sight despite London and Brussels failing to agree on how to avoid the creation of a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic.In the memo published on Wednesday, he said: Despite our differences, we are not that far from an agreement on the issue.The end is firmly in sight.The Brexit Secretary suggested November 21 as a possible date to give evidence, but promised to return &ldquowhen a deal is finalised.                Brexit BOOST: Three-quarters of UK firms remain POSITIVE about Brexit                Commons ERUPTS in laughter as Brexit meets Game of ThronesGovernment sources claim British and European Union negotiators have reached a deal on all aspects on the future partnership on series and the exchange of data.Under the agreement, UK financial services firms would be guaranteed access to European markets as long as British financial regulations remained aligned with Europe.But EU chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier warned Mrs May that the EU will never give up its right to autonomously deny access to its financial markets.Writing on Twitter, the EU negotiator said: &ldquoThe EU may grant and withdraw equivalence in some financial services autonomously.&ldquoAs with other third countries, EU is ready to have close regulatory dialogue with the UK in full respect for autonomy of both parties.News of the apparent deal broke after days of negotiating between Mrs May&rsquos EU sherpa Olly Robbins and European Commission officials in Brussels.

story: Echoing the Chancellor Philip Hammond&rsquos words, Mr Watling told the audience the UK is &ldquocoming out the recession and it is &ldquoseeing the end of many years of austerity.He said: &ldquoWe are coming out the recession, and the great British people have been utterly brilliant, they persevered.&ldquoWe are seeing the end and we are beginning to get the benefits from that.The Tory MP for Clacton, who replaced Liz Truss on the show, also noted &ldquoone of the greatest things that are happening now is that the Government is looking at big companies like Google, who &ldquohave not been paying the money they should pay for running huge businesses.                Philip Hammond LAMBASTED over decision to delay gambling reform                Budget 2018: Why was no money allocated to tackle escalating crime?Mr Watling added: &ldquoI am on the Department for Culture, Media and Sports select committee and I have seen these people close up, I have been over to America and seen what they earn.&ldquoWe have started to tax them more now and that should help us pay for the NHS.Before moving to the next question, the Tory MP also pointed out the Government is currently putting into the NHS &ldquo&pound120 billion a year, which the &ldquohighest ever in history.Mr Watling's remarks were referring to a digital services tax set to come into effect in 2020, which was introduced by Philip Hammond during his 2018 Budget in the House of Commons on Monday.A TORY MP has boasted about Philip Hammond's budget on Question Time (Image: Getty)Mr Watling told the audience the UK is &ldquocoming out the recession  (Image: Getty)The measure is predicted to raise over &pound400m a year and will likely hit tech-giants including Google, Facebook and Amazon.Mr Hammond told the Commons: The rules of the game must evolve now if they are to keep up with the emerging digital economy.It is only right that these global giants, with profitable businesses in the UK, pay their fair share towards supporting our public services.Regarding the tech-giants, Mr Hammond added: They pose a real challenge for the sustainability and fairness of our tax system.Giles Watling appeared on the BBC flagship show&rsquos panel last night  (Image: Getty) The digital services tax set to come into effect in 2020 was introduced by Philip Hammond  (Image: Getty)The rules have simply not kept pace with changing business models and it is clearly not sustainable or fair that digital platform businesses can generate substantial value in the UK without paying tax here in respect of that business.The measure will only apply to companies that are profitable and have global revenues of over &pound500m a year.However, Philip Hammond's budget was not positively welcomed by many Labour MPs in the House of Commons.Yvette Cooper, Dame Margaret Hodge and David Lammy were among the Labour MPs who opposed the budget resolution to raise the tax-free personal allowance to &pound12,500 and the higher rate income tax threshold to &pound50,000.The party had been whipped to abstain.Labour is now to propose an amendment to the budget in a bid to make clear its stance on the Government&rsquos tax cuts for higher earners.Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell said on Tuesday: We&rsquore not going to take money out of people&rsquos pockets. title: Brexit news Shappi Khorsandi BBC Question Time
story: The heated exchange was sparked when a member of the audience asked the panel if Brexit should be halted until the results of the Leave campaigner Arrons Banks enquiry are known.Mr Banks is currently being investigated by the National Crime Agency for suspected criminal offences committed during the Brexit referendum.Ms Khorsandi &ldquoneatly avoided the question and answered that Brexit &ldquoshould be halted but not because of the news about the Leave.EU funding investigations.She explained: &ldquoWe have since found out from Dominic Cummings, campaign director of Vote Leave, that without the point of immigration, they wouldn&rsquot have won, and without the promise of &pound350 to the NHS, they wouldn&rsquot have won. story: Huge landslides have occurred as a result of the magnitude 6.2 earthquake (Image: USGSRADIO PAULINA-@radiopaulina-Twitter)The quake&rsquos epicentre was located at a depth of 91 kilometres, 118 kilometres north-east of Iquique, Chile, according to the United States Geological Survey (USGS).There have been no immediate reports of casualties or damage caused by the tremor.The Chilean 24 Horas news outlet reported aftershocks from the quake instigated the mass exodus of people from Iquique beaches.Chilean media has also reported no immediate tsunami warning was issued.                Italy EARTHQUAKE: Sicily rocked by six quakes in a weekImages have emerged on social media of a vast landslide that ensued as a result of the tremor.Chilean Radio Paulina reported the major Cami&ntildea thoroughfare was impassable at 65 kilometres because of fallen debris.The radio station&rsquos website reported: &ldquoThe quake began at 7.19pm (local time) its epicentre was determined 38 kilometres south of Cami&ntildea - where the only access road to the town was blocked, at 65 kilometres.&ldquoSo far, no material damage or casualties have been recorded.Video footage has emerged online of a series of landslides (Image: RADIO PAULINA-@radiopaulina-Twitter)Amateur video footage on social media shows the encroaching landslide  (Image: RADIO PAULINA -@radiopaulina-Twitter)The USGS has reviewed the earthquake and confirmed nearby affected centres were Iquique and Arica.The city of Iquique resides on the Chilean coast, to the west of the Atacama Desert.Iquique is a popular holiday destination - thanks to its agreeable climate and ample Pacific beaches.The tax-free seaport area is home to a seafront casino and boasts a 19th-century historic centre.(L) an 'community internet intensity' map (R) a regional information map (Image: USGS)Bolivia and Peru were also affected by the earthquake&rsquos aftershocks.Basic services were affected in a few rural areas in Chile, the emergency office said.Chile is located in the so-called Ring of Fire region, which makes it one of the most seismic countries in the world.In 2010, a magnitude 8.8 earthquake and tsunami ravaged the nation, leaving 525 people dead and a further 26 missing.

title: diwali 2018 hindu festival of lights india origins
story: The festival of light sees Hindu homes decorated with candles and lights and people sharing gts - but whats the celebration all about Diwali, also known as Deepavali, is the Hindu Festival of Lights and is celebrated  every year as the spiritual victory of light over darkness.The date of the festival is calculated according to the position of the moon and the Hindu lunar calendar and is usually in October or November.In , Diwali will be celebrated on Wednesday, November  - and the festivities will last five days.Diwali is observed by Hindus, Sikhs and Jains around the world and is often marked by street parties, fireworks, new clothes and of course, delicious food.Traditional earthen diyas or candles are lit, and houses are decorated with colourful rangoli artworks – patterns created on the floor using coloured rice or powder.During the festival, families and friends share sweets and gts and there is also a strong belief in giving to those in need.It is also traditional for homes to be cleaned and new clothes to be worn.Indian sweets which come in a range of colours and flavours are also eaten during the celebrations, as well as ious rich savoury and sweet dishes.The five-day festival, which coincides with Hindu New Year, is seen to be one of the most signicant in the Indian culture.Many people celebrate the legend of Hindu God Rama and his we Sitas ing to their kingdom in northern India after being exiled following the defeat of demon king Ravanna.The word itself means series of lights and during the festival houses and shops are decorated with candles and lights.This is meant to represent light over darkness and the Hindu belief that good will always triumph over evil.For many Indians, Diwali honours Lakshmi, the goddess of wealth and people will start the new business year at Diwali and some will say prayers to the goddess for a prosperous year ahead. Indian sweetmeats - known as mithai - take centre stage during the festivities.They are nibbled throughout the day as a sweet snack, and are later served alongside a savoury dinner or snacks like samosas.Barfi - or coconut fudge - story: In a victory for The Sun, Philip Hammond will today announce a commemorative Brexit p coin, available from March , , to mark the moment we leave the EU.It will have the Queen’s head on one side and the phrase “Friendship with all nations” on the other — exactly the type of positive, outward-looking message we want to send.Despite the Remain naysayers’ claims, Britain remains a top global financial, diplomatic and military power.Unshackled from the EU, we will boom as a global business hub by developing new relationships.Despite the Government’s commemorative move, the Royal Mail refuses to release a Brexit stamp, claiming our exit will not be “an important anniversary”. What a load of codswallop!They thought it was appropriate to issue stamps commemorating TV show Game Of Thrones and for when we joined the EEC in  and the Single Market in  . . .Royal Mail bosses clearly detest the democratic decision to leave the EU.But for them to pretend Brexit is not a genuinely signicant historical moment is first-class buffoonery.IT has been a sad weekend in football.Immensely popular Leicester City owner Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha died alongside four others in a helicopter crash on Saturday night.The Thai billionaire bankrolled their  title-winning season, one of the beautul game’s greatest fairytales.The immense outpouring of grief from Foxes supporters showed how loved he was, while fans from teams as far afield as Inter Milan paid their respects alongside them on what is being described as the “darkest day” in Leicester’s history.RIP, Vichai.Meanwhile, former England star and ex-gaffer Glenn Hoddle is recovering in hospital after collapsing on TV.The reaction of footie fans and stars he played alongside, against and managed shows how well regarded he is.Get well soon, Glenn.THE proposed reform of non-disclosure agreementsis welcome.These contracts serve a purpose in some fields, such as business, where confidentiality is often necessary.But after the “Sir” Philip Green scandal last week, it is clear to all that they are being grossly misused.NDAs were not created so that the rich and powerful could gag people who make serious accusations against them.In a free society, people must always be able to blow the whistle.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: latest telethon shows us once and for all that c4s just a load of cake and balls
story: You watch BBC’s Children In Need, you’re getting Clare Balding, Doctor Who and dancers, whether you like it or not.ITV  It’d take sniper fire or a dinner setting next to Sir Phillip Green before Cowell was a no-show.Channel , though Apart from a bit of a secondhand cake-baking and Gogglebox, I was drawing a blank before Friday night.So it was with a mix of fascination and dread that I tuned into Stand Up To Cancer. A seven-hour slog live from Westminster City Hall, presented by Adam Hills, Maya Jama and the network’s spare part Alan Carr, who set the tone for most of what followed interviewing Foxy from SAS: Who Dares Wins.“It’s been announced you’ve got a new Stand Up To Cancer series starting next year. Tell us about it.”“I can’t.”“Give us some names.”“I can’t.”No sooner had we written that one off than it become apparent there was no Bake Off special either — just a promo for a show that will be screened months from now. No matter, though. With its lofty public-serving hat on, Adam Hills faithfully promised Channel  would “educate, entertain and inspire” us for the remainder of the evening, which must have looked quite good written down.In practice The first thing to say about Stand Up To Cancer is that it featured some of the most beautul and affecting films you’ll see on a telethon.They needed to be, as well, ’cos you don’t have to have watched the event to know it contained a lot of feeble stunts and sketches.I also could have lived without Adam Hills carrying out a threat to have his pubic hair waxed, live, once the total reached £million, and the educational segment, with Katherine Ryan and Chris O’Dowd, which was sunk the moment he announced: “We’re goingto put the humour in tumour.”Tellingly, there was also a fair bit of non-network talent involved, including James Corden.I’ll not dwell, though, on what Channel ’s Twitter feed did to the Carpool Karaoke segment, where Michael Buble talked about his son’s illness, except to say it was one of those productions where the left hand wasn’t talking to the right.So when Chris O’Dowd was moved to tears talking about the cancer films, the studio audience was guffawing loudly at Alan Carr manoeuvring himself into background position in a Prue Leith wig.By a process of elimination and production gaffs, though, it became apparent the centre of Channel ’s entire universe now is Gogglebox, which had created an all-star version with Louis Tomlinson, Danny Dyer and daughter Dani for the occasion.They missed a trick, frankly, by not capturing Louis falling asleep to The X Factor. But it was still riotously funny watching the regulars pick apart Naked Attraction, with the choicest comment being: “That one looks like Homer Simpson’s mouth.”This was not the sound of people laughing with the channel, though. They were laughing at it.A network that was once known for being brave and innovative is now far more readily associated with a genital parade, third-rate reality shows and cakes than anything in the way of ground-breaking drama or comedy.In fact, the only two genuinely funny people on its payroll are probably Jimmy Carr and Sean Lock, who had to make way, at Stand Up To Cancer, for box-ticking randoms like Mo Gilligan, who was served this testicular curve-ball by Maya Jama.“Do you have a special name for your balls, by any chance ”He does.The Big Narstie Show.So there I was, gently drting off as Darcey Bussell went through the technical motions on Strictly. “The control in the rise and fall. Strong in the two-three.”When, unless I’m imagining it, she told Sean Walsh: “You have to smooth it out and iron it out, so it isn’t jerking off or skippy.”Suddenly I was all ears for the show’s Halloween special – an event which, for three good reasons, is usually my least favourite of the run.Firstly, Tess always expects a laugh for referring to it as a “spook-tacular”. Secondly, someone does The ****ing Timewarp. And thirdly, the worst danceris forced to jig around to The Monster Mash.We got it all, on Saturday night, of course, yet somehow it didn’t feel quite such an endurance as normal.This may have been partly down to Ashley Roberts and Faye Tozer, who both danced like dreams, but it definitely owed something to the presence of Sean, who’s added real jeopardy to proceedings andactual comedy.His snog with Katya has made sense of a dreadful line-up and the BBC should be eternally grateful to The Sun and the photographer for capturing the moment.So although the handbag-clutchers will no doubt disagree, I was genuinely sad to see him voted off and probably back to the ex-girlfriend, where, in the words of Darcey Bussell, he’ll have to “smooth it out and iron it out” or he’ll end up, you know . . . “skippy”.Sandra Oh’s performance in Killing Eve. Aberdeen clinically dispatching some Glasgow-based team - in the Betfred Cup semi-final on Sunday.Nabhaan Rizwan heading towards the awards zone with BBC’s Informer, the best show currently on television.And the one positive to emerge from Luisa Omielan’s Politics For Bitches, which was the response from an estate agent when the “comedian” asked him what she’d have to do to afford a multi-million-pound mansion in London’s Little Venice.“Be funnier.”Since the last quarterly update, EastEnders has split into two distinct and very contrasting shows. There’s a brutal, gripping and addictive version set in Mick Carter’s prison wing, which seemed to have vanished into thin air a couple of weeks ago.And there’s the other, more familiar EastEnders we’re stuck with full-time now. A loud, grim and unforgiving place where Hayley Slater cannot decide between calling her unborn baby Stacey, in tribute to her cousin Jean, as a nod to the mad auntie, or Lee Marvin in honour of Big Mo.Worse still, though, is -year-old Keanu’s ongoing, very energetic affair with mighty Sharon Mitchell, , who’s attempted to cover the truth by claiming he’s her “personal trainer”. .“I gave him his job back,” she claimed, “He’s been getting me in shape.” The shape of what, though, is the question  An oval  A rhomboid Guy the Gorilla’s statue at London zoo An unflattering image, admittedly, but it’s nothing compared to the mental one Dot Cotton conjured up on Tuesday night, with readers of a fragile disposition advised to look away now: “Don’t play the innocent with me, Robbie Jackson. I know you’ve been fingering my Garibaldis.”See. I did warn you.This week’s winner is camp Frank, from The Apprentice, and US outlaw Jesse James.Sent in by Peter Budgen, via email. Picture research Alfie Snelling.This Morning, Rylan Clark-Neal: “Listen, you’re Martine McCutcheon, you’re a living legend.”Strictly, Tess Daly to Doctor Who’s Mandip Gill: “Congratulations on a brilliant series. It’s fantastic, isn’t it ” No.And X Factor, Ayda Field to Scarlett Lee: “You could sing the shopping list and I’d enjoy it.”Then you haven’t seen theof her shopping list.David Haye introducing himself to the winning Apprentice team as “the Hayemaker himself”.Channel  News managing to have a studio discussion about Press injunctions without anyone from the Press.The X Factor pretending Brendan Murray is “a plumber” rather than a professional musician managed by Louis Walsh.Dr Who’s latest right-on brain fart being Donald Trump and grime-loving spiders.And the BBC hiding The Mash Report behind a smokescreen of “satire” when everyone can see it’s simply spouting Auntie’s prejudices against the Tories, Brexit and working-class people.Just in case you weren’t already reminded of them on an almost hourly basis.Will there ever be a charity telethon without the deadening presence of John Bishop How come X Factor drag-act Thomas Pound’s alter-ego wasn’t Thomas Poundland Why did hardly anyone swear in Press  And where the hell did EastEnders’ prisoners all get their amazing suntans They look like they’ve just come off a fortnight’s golf in the Algarve, not a le stretch.Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which Elizabethan playwrite wrote A Midsummer Night’s Dream ”Stuart: “Pass.”The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “Kenneth Clark presented which landmark TV series on the history of art ”Andy: “The Antiques Roadshow.”Ben Shephard: “In which Latin American country is the ancient Mayan temple El Castillo ”Sue: “Egypt.”And Ben Shephard: “Northampton is the county town of which English county ”Kirsty: “Pass.”Jose Mourinho: “If Ronaldo has two touches, he can score a hat-trick.”Phil Thompson: “Elyounoussi is a flash in the pan all the time.”Steve McManaman: “United got a goal back with  minutes left and now it’s -, there’s even more time left.”Compiled by Graham WrayOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: philip hammond budget cash public money
story: Philip Hammond spoke yesterday for more than an hour. There were announcements on schools funding, defence, moving “from disposable to reusable cups across all beverage types” — even a tax break for public loos. More money for social care and Universal Credit.Shopkeepers will breathe a sigh of relief at a hefty cut to business rates.There were hints of more money for the police. Sun readers will also welcome the tax freezes on beer, spirits, cider and short-haul flights.But the big bucks — some £.billion of the £.billion extra the Government expects to spend come - — went to the NHS, fulfilling the Prime Minister’s summer promise to increase spending as a th birthday present to a health service creaking under the strain of an ageing population.The question, of course, was how the Chancellor was going to pay for it.Before the Budget, all sorts of grim possibilities had been floated.Extra taxes on white-van men, lower- ing the VAT threshold and tightening the rules about National Insurance contributions. Taxes on plastic cups . Taxes on pretty much anything, really.Perhaps the best thing the Chancellor did in his Budget, then, was say “No”.To almost all of it. For an hour or more, I waited for the sting in the tail — the bit where Fiscal Phil turned Hatchet Hammond.But it never came. In paying for his promises — and above all, the NHS — the Chancellor was helped by better-than-expected borrowing forecasts, which showed our economy’s remarkable record of creating jobs is still going strong.But he has also made a calculation that it is better to live with a small and manageable deficit than try to drag the finances back into surplus at the cost of higher taxes. And that voters will see through Labour’s promises to hike borrowing back to stratospheric levels in the name of a socialist transformation of the economy.He decided, in other words, people pay enough tax already.And he’s right. All too often in recent years, it has felt like the answer to every problem — at least from Whitehall’s point of view — is higher taxes and more interference.Hammond was never going to copy his tax-slashing Tory predecessor Nigel Lawson, who made it a point of principle to abolish a dferent tax with every Budget.But at least he drew a line in the sand, deciding it is better when hardworking people get to keep more of their own money.That ending austerity should not, and must not, mean higher tax bills. That hard work should mean hard cash in your pocket.Yes, Hammond — like every Chancellor since Gordon Brown — made too many fiddly little announcements.But he avoided the kind of whacking- great raid on taxpayers’ pockets so many were urging him towards.This doesn’t mean we are out of the woods. Britain’s growth prospects over the next half-decade are still extraordinarily sluggish.The outcome of the Brexit deal will drastically change the fiscal picture.In many ways, Hammond’s speech yesterday was a holding action ahead of the much bigger decisions to come.We still need much more radical action to kickstart growth and productivity. Despite the scale of the housing crisis, for example, there was only tinkering around the edges.But a large part of delivering that growth must involve making the economy more dynamic, more competitive and letting people keep more of their own money as a reward for their efforts — moving the country in the direction outlined by Philip Hammond, rather than the one sketched out by Jeremy Corbyn .The overall verdict on the Budget  The jokes were worse than expected but the numbers were better.More spending on the NHS, tax cuts for millions of voters and the worst ideas kept out of it.Yes, borrowing will be higher — but low enough to keep us out of the danger zone and far, far lower than under a Corbyn government.That is a menu Philip Hammond will be pretty happy with.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
